ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about banking crises mainly and more generally about the role of the banks. Also I learned about macroprudential policies which are very important. The course was enlightening about the recent global financial crisis too.
I learned about macro-prudential policy, and the various drivers behind financial crises from two experts in the field

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of the course is that it combines theory and data and gives a broad view of banking crises and the role of the banks. The weakness of the course is that it focuses only on banks. There are other financial crises, such as sovereign debt crises, or currency crushes that create greater problems in an economy hit by such shocks than a banking crisis. We discussed very little about such events.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if a student is interested in banking and crises related to banks I will recommend it for sure.
Take it!! Dont be afraid as an undergrad, professors are super approachable and grading is very fair. It is a must take for anyone
